sp.p: And I will rather die a shameful death, then live a hateful life, which I must do unless I find a means that may deserve your love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
No we your tongue goes like a well tuned instrument, and makes my heart within my bosom dance with joy to hear such large requital of my love: but durst you to maintain this your affection, although it
were with some danger of your life?

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: Dared I? I vow, even by my soul's eternity, I durst.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Alas, if you knew all, 'tis your own good, not mine: and yet I lie, 'tis my good too, since my life depends upon your safety.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: What is't dear lady? although it be the death of man, if it be pleasing unto you I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: O let me embrace so dear a spirit in so dear a bosom: and since you have bound yourself by promise, I will be plain, there are two that hate you two, because we love you, and often have persuaded us by gifts and large protestations to have us love them if they killed you.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: What us?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Who we?

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Nay 'tis too true; for while you lived, they said there was no hope for them to look for any love from us: now we poor silly women, fearing lest they without consent of us, should do that which their hatred doth intend, we think it fit prevention first be used, by giving them to drink of what themselves have brewed.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: First murder them.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: True, so shall ye then be sure,
T'enjoy our loves, we yours, and live secure.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: But what are they ladies?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Spark.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And Ruffell.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.p: They die for't though they were my father's sons.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: They shall not live.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: Let little children fear the shallow brooks, for I can swim though't be through seas of blood; let foolish fear go dwell with women, for bloody resolution shall not part from me, I'll kill them both even with mine own hands, I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O no ▪ I'll reveal it then, unless you first do swear and take a sacrament, whatever hap to keep our names untouched.

sp.speaker: Piso
sp.p: Untouched? we'll do't.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Then for the means:

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: We'll stab them.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: We'll fight with them.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: No, so you may miss them, and they kill you.

sp.speaker: Fel:
sp.p: Give them a fig.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: Make them drink their last.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Poison them:

sp.speaker: Piso
sp.p: But for the means.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: You two shall make a banquet, and in a cup of wine a health shall pass.

sp.speaker: Piso:
sp.p: In which I'll mingle mingle such a dram, as they shall ride to heaven in post, unless they miss the way.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: But where shall we get the poison? because you know 'tis dangerous, and will breed suspect where ere we buy it.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.p: I have a countryman in town an apothecary, one signior Aluino, a fellow that is well stored, and will sell me of the best.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: If 'a were of my mind, 'a would think no poison too good for you.

sp.speaker: Flo
sp.p: Come then, I would have you go about the preparation of the feast.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Now boys, you have a couple of goodly masters,

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I Fleir, and thou hast a couple of virtuous mistresses, oh they are a couple of damned pieces, that will plot or counsel the death of two such worthy gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: For one of them the earth did never bear a worthier creature.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Which is that?

sp.speaker: Su,
sp.p: Which is that? Why sister, have you so oft confessed that his all perfectioned spirit points him out for virtue herself to imitate, and yet d'ye ask now which is that?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: How? sister, nay now I smell you i'faith, d'ye hear, d'ye hear, whose fiddlers are you two? what instruments do you bear I pray?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You have told a wise tale, faith fir we carry none.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: 'Tis true my little musicians, you carry but the cases my little curtals, i'faith I smell a smock here too, and are you two wenches i'faith?

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: If we were, I hope thou wouldst not wrong us.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: No, as I am true Italian born.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Then 'tis true, we confess to thee we are both wenches, and the love of these two gentlemen, spark and Ruffel hath made us leave ourselves to wait on them which by misfortune we did miss.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: But believe me my little gallants, ye play the boys well.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Well? why I'll tell thee, I have played the boy so long as I am changed into the nature of a boy, I'll go to span-counter with any page in Europe, for his best garters I can tell bawdy tales, drink drunk, brag, swear, and lie with any lackey in the town.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: I can man a punk to a play, or slander any gentlewoman as well as any inns a court puny, I can as well as he, swear such a lady is in love with me, and such a citizen's daughter would have come to bed to me, when all shall be as true as thy ladies are honest.

sp.speaker: Na
sp.p: I wonder thou'lt live in such a sinful place.

sp.speaker: Su:
sp.p: Thy ladies are as common as any tavern door.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Good comparisons, for a man comes no sooner into a tavern, but he's welcome, and the operation of the pot makes him not able to stand when he comes out.

sp.speaker: Na,
sp.p: But what shall we do in this matter?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Do? Why complain them to the magistrates, and prevent the murder.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: No, not so, I'll tell you how't shall be, hark in your ears.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.l: Do it and we shall ever thank thee.
Come let's about it then.

div.stage: Enter signior Alunio the apothecary in his shop with wares about him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
What's this? O this is Arringus; this makes the old man able, and the young man lusty, strengtheneth the
nerves and doth concoct the blood, and her name is written on the box, because my wife should know it in my absence: this is civet, this comes from the cat's tail, I would my were such a cat: this perfumes your ladies, and not without cause, for some, I mean whose sweet breath is dead, and teeth mourn in black for the loss on't this makes your young gallants smell them nine days before they see them, like young poops: this drug is precious and dear; what's this? O this is the spirit of roses, nineteen bushels and a half of roses make but an ounce, and a dram on't, 'tis made of the quintessence of the water after the fifteenth distillation: none may kiss a lady after she hath anointed her lips with this, under the degree of a lord at least, 'tis worth nine pounds an ounce, yet I could never still it so.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Save you signior.

sp.speaker: Alu:
sp.p: You're welcome sir, what do ye lack?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I want a service, and am by my profession an apothecary, and shall be glad to be entertained by you.

sp.speaker: Alu:
sp.p: What country man art thou?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I am a florentine born.

sp.speaker: Alu,
sp.p: Thou art my country man, and therefore welcome and in happy time, for I am bound for Italy, and want a man to take charge of my shop, only this is all: I shall require of you, be careful of your cares, and obedient to your mistress.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I shall remember still not to forget what you give me in charge.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.p: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Jacomo.

sp.speaker: Alu:
sp.p: Well Jacomo, if I find thee honest thou shalt find me liberal.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I would be loath to be found otherwise.

sp.speaker: Alu:
sp.p: Continue so, I prithee, and so farewell Jaques, but I'll inform my wife before I go to respect thee according to thy merit.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Now come away my customers, I hope I am fitted for an apothecary ▪ s'hart I think I'm turned conjurer, for I have no sooner called ▪ but the devils are appeared, what do ye lack gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Where's your master fellow?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: My master is gone into Italy sir, but if you want any thing, I'll use you well, if you want any drugs to make lotions, any restringent powders, any aqua mirabilis, any cordial receipts, or any precious poisons?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: What poisons have you?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Excellent good sir, as ever was tasted, look you sir, this poisons by the smell, this by the sight, and this by the tastes.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Come give me some of this that poisons by the taste, but how must I use it?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Put it into a little wine, and drink it, 'twill bring you into a long sleep.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: But art sure 'twill poison a man?

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Am I sure on't? why take't upon my credit, 'twill poison any vermin, except it be a woman, for 'twill poison a cat sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why a cat hath nine lives sir, and wilt not poison a woman, seeing 'twill poison a cat?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: O no, why a woman hath nine cats lives, a woman hath more lives than a horse hath diseases, and she will be sometimes in as many minds in an hour, as she has lives.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: What times are those?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: When she's left a rich merchant's widow, commonly, and hath many suitors, she will in her mind marry three or four and fifty of 'em in an afternoon, and threescore more, when she goes to bed, yet in the morning she'll have none of them all, but go to church before day, and marry her prentice for the good service 'a did her in her husband's time.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Well, but what's the price of your poison?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: There's an ounce will cost you a French crown sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: 'Tis very dear.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O sir 'tis very cheap, considering the goodness on't.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Yea? is there good in ill?

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: O sir, ay, in many things the better the worser.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: As in poison, or in a punk, for the better whore the worser woman ever.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: Well honest fellow, there's thy money and farewell.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: I thank you sir, I have sold you a poison my old elders, 'twill make any sleep indeed, and I thank God that's the worst 'twill do, well, farewell master apothecary. I must now like a friend entreat your shop to have a special care of itself.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: And shall we dine with this honourable lord, and knight today?

sp.speaker: Spa,
sp.p: They'll take it unkindly else.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Signior will you go?

sp.speaker: Pet ▪
sp.p: Not I, I was not bid.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: That's all one, shalt be my guest.

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: Come, 'a shall go, for there will be his mistress madam Fromaga.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Nay then I know the jet of her complexion will draw the straw of his love thither.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Faith I, poor signior, I see the springle of her beauty hath already caught the woodcock of his affections.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: Well, I see he that will have the commodity of good wits in his company, must endure the discommodity of jests, wit is like the heat of blood in youth 'twil break out.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: True signior, though it be but on a scab, but come shall we go?

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: I my heroic spirits, I'll follow ye.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter Petoune one way, and Nan the page another way.

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: O signior Petoune, what news?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Faith ill news, the two Florentine ladies, with master spark and master Ruffell were all poisoned yesterday at a feast by your lord Piso and the knight, but the ladies have recovered their health, but spark and Ruffell are dead, and their burial is committed to Fleire: your lord and the knight are committed to prison, and shall tomorrow be arraigned for the murder, and tried by the civil-law, because your lord is a stranger, and claims to be tried by the law of nations.

sp.speaker: Nan:
sp.p: Faith signior I am very sorry for my lord.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: I protest sir so am I for them both.

sp.speaker: Nan,
sp.p: Well signior I'll commit you to God.

sp.speaker: Pet,
sp.p: Let the whole band of angels be sentinels to your safety sweet sir.

div.stage: Enter Fleire at one door: and a servingman at another.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: I pray sir doth justice Ferrio dwell here?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes sir 'a dwells here.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Are you towards him sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I am a poor gentleman, whose fortunes much depend upon his favours, and indeed sir I am his clerk.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I pray sir your name.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: My name is mittimus sir.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Good master mittimus I would very willingly speak with your master.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Indeed sir he's not well, but if you please to send by me the substance of your business I shall very carefully deliver it.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p:
Truly master mittimus my business is but this: tomorrow the Italian lord, and sir John Have-little are to
be arraigned, and your master being the chief judge of the court, without this presence or licence, the rest can do nothing: wherefore doctor Caius entreats to know his pleasure in this business.

sp.speaker: Mitti:
sp.p: Sir I shall deliver your message, and will return his answer to you presently.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Good master mittimus therein shall you much oblige me to be thankful.
sp.l: O all-directing power yield good aspect,
And to my purpose give a blessed end,
My intent is good, oh let it so succeed,
And be auspicious still to each good deed.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir my master hath received your message, and hath sent this ring as a token to doctor Caius, desiring him, since my master's health will not permit him to be present, to proceed alone to judgement, and so commends his love to him.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Good master mittimus, I shall both deliver your master's commendations, and the ring.

div.stage: Enter lord Piso with a torch, a nightcap, and his doublet open: in prison.

sp.speaker: Piso.
sp.l: Still tongueless night put off thy sable robe,
Thou needs not mourn, my villainies were done
sp.p: By day, thou hadst no hand in them, oh I am great, as is a woman that is near her time:
sp.l: And life's the burden that I bear.
But 'tis a bastard for that I am ashamed on't.
sp.p: The law I hope is a skilful midwife, and will soon deliver me; grim justice do thy worst,
sp.l: Thy cruelty shall prove a courtesy,
And bail me out of prison.
sp.p: Lie there thou self-consuming taper, true pattern of my life, I have consumed myself for others, as thou hast done for me, and now she has extinguished my life as I this light.
sp.l: O how obedient was my bounty, still
To her command? my liberality
Did fatten mischief, and hath made her proud:
Oh that too much of any thing should be so ill in every thing
The suns all seeing eye, with too much untemperate heat makes wither what it made to flourish.
The earth being mother to all wholesome herbs,
With too much fatness oft produceth weeds.
A suit of cloth doth keep the body warm,
When richer garments makes the wearer proud.
O, the means the sweetest music;
Contentment revels when that string is touched;
But oh, the time will come she will repent
My death: for when she looks on vices face
Unmask like mine; she will detest and loathe it.
For this is truth and evermore hath been,
None can forsake before he knows his sin.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Come, come, thou didst but dream thou wert in hell.

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: I tell thee I was in hell.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And so was I too, I'll be sworn.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: And how long was't ere thou camest thither?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: methought was long, as long as a suit hangs here in the law ere it be ended.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: But I prithee how broad was the way to hell?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: As broad as the space between two lines in a chancery bill.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: O sir, there's the conscience on't, say the plaintiff be in one line, and the defendant in another, they being enemies, were't either conscience or honesty in the clerk to thrust them no near together, that they might go together by th'ears? but i'faith what good fellowship was there in hell?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: O the devils are excellent companions, they'll drink your Dutch captains, or court ladies' sponges.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Who didst see there?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Faith I saw the four sons of Aymon, and they were porters ever since there was a company made of am.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Why are there a company of porters in hell?

sp.speaker: Sp,
sp.p: O ay, the devils are but our ape's man.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: But didst thou see more of them that were damned ▪

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Yes, I saw a citizen damned for refusing a desperate debt, because was tendered him on a sabbath.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: I hope we shall have no more citizens damned for that fault.

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: There was a poor mercenary woman damned because she forsook her trade, and turned Puritan.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: And good reason, why could not she have kept her trade, and been a Puritan, as well as a Puritan keep her religion, and yet be of her trade?

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: There was a lady damned because she never painted: a Puritan for saying grace without turning up the white of his eyes: a tailor for never having scabby fingers: a vintner for making great two pennyworths of sugar. But there was a inns of court man damned, and I was sorry for him.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Why was he damned?

sp.speaker: Sp:
sp.p: Alas for a small fault.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I prithee what wast?

sp.speaker: Spar:
sp.p: For having always money in his purse.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Were there no lawyers in hell?

sp.speaker: Spar.
sp.p: There were none of your great lawyers as your sergeants, and benchers, for they take counsel of too many good angels to come there: but your young puny lawyers, they were in swarms like gnats in summer.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Why are there so many of them there?

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
Alas man they seldom converse with a good angel scarce once in a whole Michaelmas term, and if 'a come 'a stays not long with am to feed these souls, for they are fain to send am away straight to
pay for the feeding of their horses, there was a chambermaid damned for keeping her virginity till she was married, and there were many soldiers damned for saying their prayers when they were drunk.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: But what didst thou see in hell?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: O, I saw a scrivener damned for procuring a gentleman money gratis, but I came in an excellent time.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: What time was't?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: In a gossipping time, for Proserpina was newly brought a-bed of two twins.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: Two twins! what were they?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: A sergeant and a yeoman, but she has put them out to nurse.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: I prithee where?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Faith at the counter in wood-street, and the slaves will suck already like little horseleeches.

sp.speaker: Fl:
sp.p: But when will she have an home, that she may be rid of am.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: Faith she's an unnatural mother, she cares not greatly if they never come home, but the devil their father he loves am well, he'll have am home again ere long.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Which is the elder brother?

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: O the sergeant, the devil allows him the better maintenance, for he has more to the dressing of his meat.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, since by the heaven's pleasure I have been appointed to save your lives, let me entreat you to keep yourselves secret till the sequel of this action shall need your presence.

sp.speaker: Ruff,
sp.p: Come let's go, we'll only follow your directions.

div.stage: Enter two judges with their train, and sit down.

sp.speaker: Jailor.
sp.p: Will't please ye have the prisoners brought forth?

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: We can do nothing till we hear from doctor Ferrio, to know his pleasure in these proceedings.

sp.speaker: 2. Iudges.
sp.p: Was any man sent to him?

sp.speaker: Caius,
sp.p: Yes, Fleire, the lady Florida's man, which is not yet returned.

sp.speaker: Jailor,
sp.p: Reverend judges: here's a doctor at door desires admittance.

sp.speaker: Caius,
sp.p: Entreat him to come in.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Learned doctors, doctor Ferrio commends him to you, and because sickness hath laid so strong a hand upon his weak decrepit body, which doth detain his presence, he entreats you to accept of me in his place, and as assurance of his earnest desire thereof, he has sent this well known ring as a token to you.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Sir, we know the ring and you are very welcome, and so I pray assume his place.

sp.speaker: Jailor,
sp.p: Is it your pleasure the prisoners be brought forth.

sp.speaker: Caius,
sp.p: Ay, both of them.

div.stage: Enter Piso knight, two ladies, two wenches, Nan and Sue, Petoune, Fromaga.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: My lord, you are here indicted of a hateful crime, and I am very sorry to see you in this sort stand here.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Thrice reverend judges, and therefore honoured lords, I must confess, that like a skilful dancer, I have truly footed folly, yet like a learner in my course of life, trod much out of measure, I have lived like an unbacked colt proud and wanton, my tree of life hath born more leaves than fruit, I never was debauched and steered away my days even in a sea of sin.

sp.speaker: Caius,
sp.p: And in, that sea my lord, you bore so great a sail as you have over set your bark of life, and here you are accused my lord, even of a hateful crime, so is the knight there for poisoning two gentlemen, spark and Ruffell, how do you answer this my lord?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Alas my lord, this is soon answered, for though that I have surfeited on sin, yet have I not been drunk with blood.

sp.speaker: Caius:
sp.p: What say you knight?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: The crime is great I must confess my lord, but I am sure the proof can be but little.

sp.speaker: Cai:
sp.p: Ladies you know most, and therefore 'tis fittest most you speak.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.p: Why then my lord, this is all we can say, this lord and knight feasted divers of us their friends, but four of us he drenched with such a dram which soon made two discharge the debt they owed to nature.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: O conscience wouldst thou give me leave!

sp.speaker: Fal:
sp.p: And we no doubt my lords, had long ere this breathed out our lives like them, but that we had the lesser quantity, for being esteemed the weaker vessels, they thought the lesser blow would break us.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: O had not death arrested me.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Why then my lord, we thus must now proceed, they that spilt innocent blood themselves must bleed; but ladies I have heard you had a man called Fleire, what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: He was sent to doctor Ferrio, and we never saw him since.

sp.speaker: Fl,
sp.p: Do you know his hand ladies?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: I pray look here then.

sp.speaker: Flo:
sp.p: This is his hand indeed.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I very perfectly do know it to be his.

sp.speaker: Fle
sp.p: Why then upon this hand I hear arrest you both, upon your lives.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Who, we?

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Ay, you ladies, my lord I pray you, read this letter.

body.p: Reverend judges, God will by some means punish every sin, and though against my will, yet by my conscience I am enforced to unmask my lady's vilianies, the murder for which the lord and knight are like to die, was first plotted by them: the two pages with myself did hear it: the prisoners in this action, are enforced by sacrament to be secret, and thus entreating heaven in justice, still to aid you.

sp.speaker: Caius
sp.p: Is this true my lord?

sp.speaker: 2, judge,
sp.p: They are sworn not to reveal it,

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: But being revealed they may affirm it.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.p: 'Tis too true my lord.

sp.speaker: Fle,
sp.p: Where are the pages?

sp.speaker: Both,
sp.p: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.p: How say you boys to this letter?

sp.speaker: Both,
sp.p: The letter speaks nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: Fle:
sp.p: Well ladies, than we here pronounce this sentence that you must die among the rest.

sp.speaker: Flo,
sp.l: You powers divine, I know do plainly see,
Heaven's starry eyes sees all our villainy:
And God in justice murder will reveal,
But were I now, my life for to begin,
sp.p: I'd be an honest wife to you, wherefore forgive me dearest lord.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.l: Lady, I do even as I hope to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Show mercy heaven, my sins do thee offend,
There's none can say he's happy till his end;
Forgiveness knight, and since the law on us,
Hath laid so strict a hand, oh let me be
Thy wife before I die, and were I now
A thousand years to live, I would be honest
Loving none but thee.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I do forgive you lady with my soul.

div.stage: Enter a messenger with letters to Piso.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Long live my honoured lord and mighty Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Pis,
sp.p: So 'a will, as long as't please the hangman.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: My honoured lord, your father is deceased, and the state of Florence by me hath sent their letters and allegiance.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Let them call back the banished signior antifront whom they and we, and all have wronged: oh could I live but to inquire him out, in satisfaction of his wrongs, I'd marry his eldest daughter, and whilst a lived a should be restored to his estate, but oh he's —

div.stage: Fleire shows himself to be antifront,

sp.speaker: Fle.
sp.l: Here my lord.
I tax you to your word, signior Antifront yet lives,
And here's his elder daughter whom himself
But now condemned to die: and here's the younger
Left for you, the poisoned men are here alive again,
Who did but dream of death, but yet do
Live to enrich a nuptial bed to you two,
And now since every thing so well doth sort,
Let all be pleased in this our comic sport,
Where's Petoune? he shall have his mistress too,
He most deserves, for he did hotly woe,
If we part friends, your hands unto us lend,
What was not well, we'll next strive to amend.
